item.term: Early first millennium to the fourth century BC (predominance of Saba)
Fourth to first centuries BC (predominance of Qataban and Hadramawt, and their alliance with Main)
First century BC to early second century AD (alliances between the tribes of the high plateau and the ASA kingdoms)
Late second to late third centuries AD (wars among the Himyar, Saba and Hadramawt)
Fourth to sixth centuries AD (unification of Yemen under Himyarite rule)

ʿAlhān Nahfān and his son Shāʿirum ʾAwtar, King of Sabaʾ, son of Yar-
īm ʾAyman, King of Sabaʾ, have dedicated to their patron-god Taʾlab
Riyāmum, Lord of Turʿat, three statues of bronze, out of gratitude because
Taʾlab granted them a favor through the completion of all the plantations of ṭyb-incense and ṣrf-incense which they had laid out? and set up
for their residence of Yahgal--
plots of ṣrf-incense--and the completion of all of their plantation and all of
their irrigation channels and plantations as far as the irrigated lands of the ʿimd-trees and the ṣwrt-plantation and the buttresses in the irrigated lands of the ʿimd-trees and the plantations
and all of the water channels of the irrigation scheme and the water deflector, and all of the ṣwrt-plantations of Qayharān which they had laid out? in
the north, as far as the town of Laqiṭ and for the agricultural estate--eight plots--and all of their plantation
and the water channels of the irrigation scheme and its irrigation apparatus and all of the furnishing of that agricultural estate in sum total; and out of gratitude
because Gǝdūrā, King of the Ethiopians, had sent and dispatched to him a mission to establish an alliance with him.

whether for war or for peace, with regard to anyone who might rise up against them in war, and that with rectitude
and fidelity Salḥīn and Zararān and ʿAlhān and Gǝdūrā might be allied, each unto the other. And they expressed gratitude
because their alliance was realized with the king of the Ethiopians; and out of gratitude because he i.e. Taʾlab protected all of
the qayls and lieutenants who were sent, one man unto his ally, by sea and by land, and all the dispat- ches and gifts which they sent, each man to his fellow; and out of gratitude because
ʿAmmīʾanas bin Śinḥān and the tribe of Khawlān were defeated in a war which they had initiated and through which they had rebelled against
their lords, the kings of Sabaʾ, and because they sent Shabbat of the clan of ʿIlayyān to he of Raydān in order to aid
them i.e. the Ḥimyarites in a war against their lords, the kings of Sabaʾ, and some of the Sabaean confederation took the field to exact reprisals
on them in that war which they had initiated, and they vanquished some of Ḥaqlān and ravaged all of
its terraced vineyards, and after that they surrendered to their lord ʿAlhān, the king of Sabaʾ, and they sent two
hostages: ʾAshmas bin Riyāmum and Ḥārith bin Yadīm. And may Taʾlab grant them prosperity
and good fortune and the destruction and humiliation of their enemies and their foes. By Taʾlab Riyāmum.
